name: Irène Joliot-Curie
summary: Nobel Prize-winning physicist and chemist who discovered artificial radioactivity with her husband Frédéric Joliot-Curie.
shortDescription: Irène Joliot-Curie was a French physicist and chemist who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1935 for discovering artificial radioactivity. She was the daughter of Marie Curie and continued her mother's groundbreaking work in radioactivity. Her discoveries opened new possibilities in nuclear medicine and physics.

detailed_description.early_life: Born in 1897 in Paris, Irène was the daughter of Marie and Pierre Curie. She grew up surrounded by science and was educated at home before attending the Sorbonne.
detailed_description.stem_journey: Irène began her career working with her mother Marie Curie at the Radium Institute. She later worked with her husband Frédéric Joliot-Curie, making groundbreaking discoveries in nuclear physics.
detailed_description.challenges: As a woman in physics and chemistry, Irène faced gender discrimination. She also faced challenges during World War II and the Nazi occupation of France.
detailed_description.achievements: Irène discovered artificial radioactivity with her husband, earning them the Nobel Prize in Chemistry. She made numerous contributions to nuclear physics and chemistry.
detailed_description.legacy: Irène's work on artificial radioactivity opened new possibilities in nuclear medicine and physics. She continued her mother's legacy and inspired future generations of women scientists.
